question.title: Problem with Specificsfion and Strategy design pattern
question.body:
I’m writing with a question I encountered in my project. I have one superclass and three subclasses, which inherit attributes from the superclass, and each subclass has its own specific attribute. I need to implement filtering with any combination of parameters (using Specifications). I’m not sure how to apply the Strategy pattern here.

I tried something like having a VehicleSpecification(name, power) and, for example, BikeSpecification(name, power, size), TankSpecification(name, power, pipeLength), and maybe some interface for this, but honestly, I’m not sure. Here comes the question of the BikeService, where I don’t know how to structure everything so that it works with the Strategy design pattern.

answers.body:
What is your actual problem you're trying to solve, though? (or is this a CS/SE homework assignment?)

Also, please clarify exactly what you mean by "specification" here, because I think you mean "specialization", but I'm uncertain. And what is your BikeService?

I noticed you're using Java - which by-virtue of the limited expressiveness of its type-system, means people (and Enterprises) tend to overuse design-patterns (even worse: those GoF design-patterns were designed for languages with richer conceptions of OOP like C++ and Smalltalk, hence the pain).
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/system-design/strategy-pattern-set-1/ - I wanted this to just be a comment. SO sucks.

Sorry, missclick I ment about VehicleService and the programming language is Java.

Specification is the interface in Java.
